awd_titl_txt: Novel States in Spin-Orbit-Coupled and Correlated Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Modern condensed matter physics research has produced novel materials with fundamental properties that underpin a remarkable number of cutting-edge technologies. It is now generally accepted that novel materials are necessary for critical advances in technologies and whoever discovers novel materials generally controls the science and technology of the future. Transition metal oxides have attracted enormous interest within both the basic and applied science communities.  However, for many decades, the overwhelming balance of effort was focused on the 3d-elements (such as iron, copper, etc.) and their compounds; the heavier 4d- and 5d-elements (such as ruthenium, iridium, etc., which constitute two thirds of the d-elements listed in the Periodic Table) and their compounds have been largely ignored until recently. The principal investigator seeks to discover novel materials containing 4d- and/or 5d-elements and understand how they offer wide-ranging opportunities for the discovery of new physics and, ultimately, new device paradigms. This project also provides rigorous training to all students involved, focusing on synthesis and characterization techniques covering a broad spectrum of materials and experimental probes available in the principal investigator's laboratory.  

Technical Abstract:
Physics driven by spin-orbit interactions is among the most important topics in contemporary condensed matter physics. Since the spin-orbit interaction is comparable to the on-site Coulomb and other relevant interactions, it creates a unique balance between competing interactions that drive complex behaviors and exotic states not observed in other materials. The project encompasses a systematic effort to elucidate physics of novel phenomena in spin-orbit-coupled and correlated materials and a rigorous search for new materials having exotic ground states. This project focuses on the following areas: (1) Novel phenomena at high pressures and high magnetic fields, (2) Unusual correlations between the insulating gap and magnetic transition in iridates and ruthenates, (3) Exotic metallic and superconducting states in iridates, (4) Mott insulators with "intermediate-strength" spin-orbit interaction and other competing energies, and (5) Single-crystal synthesis and search for novel materials. The principal investigator is one of a few key pioneers who have initiated seminal studies on iridates and, before that, ruthenates, and has comprehensive facilities and proven expertise for single-crystal synthesis and wide-ranging studies of structural, transport, magnetic, thermal and dielectric properties as functions of temperature, magnetic field, pressure and doping.

Intellectual Merit 

During this award period, the PI has primarily focused on discovery and study of new quantum materials containing heavy transition metals. A primary driver of the unique properties of these materials is strong spin-orbit interactions. Our research has helped initiate rapidly growing fields of research on these materials that are of great fundamental and technological significance.  

 Some Representative Advances during the Award Period 

1. The Challenge of Spin-Orbit-Tuned Ground States in Iridates - A Key Issues Review The PI has conducted an experimental survey of iridates, a novel class of quantum materials. These materials exhibit empirical trends that are markedly different from that of other materials. An invited review of experimental studies of iridates by the PI and P. Schlottmann is published in Report on Physics in Physics as A Key Issues Review. 

2. Discovery of electrical-current-controlled quantum states in iridates and ruthenates: Electrical control of quantum states is a long-sought goal. The PI discovered current-control of structural/physical properties in certain spin-orbit-coupled materials (Fig.1). This discovery presents a new paradigm for the effects of strong spin-orbit interactions in condensed matter and points the way to novel possibilities for functional materials and devices. This study has now inaugurated a key, new research topic.

3. Discovery of a rare insulating state persistent up to 185 GPa in Sr2IrO4: It reveals a novel type of electronic Coulomb correlation that compensates the anticipated band broadening in strongly spin-orbit-coupled materials at megabar pressures (see Fig.2), sharply contrasting the traditionally expected metallization under pressure. 

4. First synthesized or discovered many of now widely investigated iridates in single-crystal form, which has stimulated rapidly advancing studies of strongly spin-orbit-coupled materials (Fig.3). 

Broader Impacts

 Journal Publications: 30 papers, including one invited Key Issues Review in Reports on Progress in Physics and three Physical Review Letters. 

Invited Talks: 26 invited talks.

Conference and Symposium Organizer/Chair: (a) 2019 APS March Meeting Focus Topic: 4d and 5d Transition Metal Systems, (b) Joint Session of APS and CPS at 2017 CPS Annual Meeting, Chengdu, China, September 7-12, 2017. 

 Patent Application:  Title: Electrical-Current Control of Structural and Physical Properties via Strong Spin-Orbit Interactions in Canted Antiferromagnetic Mott Insulators. 

 Collaborations:  The PI has established broad and active collaborations with more than two dozen leading scientists. We have generated high-quality single crystals of 4d and 5d transition metal oxides in support of our extensive collaborations necessary to advance our collective understanding of the novel phenomena under study. 

PhD Students:  Six Ph.D. students were either fully or partially supported by the grant: Jasminka Terzic (female), Hao Zheng, Hengdi Zhao, Daniel Steckhahn, Yu Zheng and Yifei Ni. Terzic graduated with Ph.D. in 2017.  

Summary

The PI has played a leading role in the development of the field of 4d/5d transition metal oxides. His pioneering studies of spin-orbit-coupled iridates that have helped initiate a key research field that has several sessions at the APS March Meeting in recent years.  These spin-orbit-coupled materials create a unique interplay of strong spin-orbit interactions and correlations that results in exotic states never or seldom seen in other materials, and have been among the most contemporary, extensively investigated materials.

During this award period, the PI has discovered a wide range of novel quantum phenomena and materials and generated over 30 publications and delivered 26 invited talks at major conferences, universities and national labs. His work has made a substantial impact in the field of correlated electron materials and been cited more than 11,400 times; his h-index is 54 [Google Scholar]. He is one of the three most highly cited researchers in the area of 5d-oxides. 

In particular, the PI made a discovery of electrical-current-controlled quantum states in certain spin-orbit-coupled materials, which has now inaugurated a key, new research topic. Electrical control of quantum states is a long-sought goal, which is now within reach. In essence, application of small electrical current to spin-orbit-coupled antiferromagnetscan effectively control structural and physical properties, resulting in nonequilibrium, exotic quantum states never or seldom seen in ambient situations.  A key characteristic of these materials is an extremely strong magnetoelastic coupling via spin-orbit interactions. Because of it, applied electrical current that engages with orbitals/lattice can effectively control magnetic and electronic states. The PI has investigated structural, magnetic and transport properties of these spin-orbit-coupled materials as a function of electrical current as well as magnetic field and temperature.

The PI has also established broad and active collaborations with more than two dozen leading scientists. We have generated high-quality single crystals of 4d and 5d transition metal oxides in support of our extensive collaborations necessary to advance our collective understanding of the novel phenomena under study. 

 The PI emphasizes that it is the NSF award that has made all these achievements possible.
